ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about the scientific research community, both in and out of academia, and I learned strategies to read a scientific paper. We also had many conversations with upperclassmen, graduate students, DUSs, and librarians, which helped me understand the resources Yale has for undergraduates in STEM fields.
Learned to read academic papers, write better academic papers, and how research is done.
Reading scientific papers in math, physics, and computer science. How to articulate scientific information in a manner more digestible to the layperson. Engaging presentation of scientific material.

This course taught me the importance of concision and clarity, especially in the context of scientific literature. The seminar format of the class has also been beneficial in facilitating group discussions and the flow of ideas between other students and me.
I learned how to read scientific articles and better convey my knowledge to others.
I learned how to read, evaluate, and report on scientific papers.
I learned a new approach to research and its uses.
This class helped me develop skills in reading and writing as well as understanding scientific research papers.

You can learn a lot in the field you might be interested in. Professor Bailyn is always optimistic about the personal topics you want to study in research. I have learned a lot about the Theory of Deep Learning, how to analyze papers, and how to proofread them. As a good chance, you will attend some science events organized by other institutions, such as Quantum Computing, and can learn a lot about other exciting topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: You learn about scientific research and make connections with other faculty and students. You become a clearer writer and learn how to present scientific information.
Weaknesses: This is really only helpful if you have your heart set on doing STEM research. Most of our conversations were geared towards how to make a career in science, which is great if that is your life plan.

Strengths: Helps students explore the topics they want to research, gives resources for students to find research, and helps to lead students.
Weaknesses: None really
I thought the class was excellent all around, but I think there could be more opportunities for conversation between students.
I loved that this course was very different from a lecture style course and was mostly discussion based.

I really liked the format, and I think that the discussion aspect of the class was great. However, I would've liked more feedback on progress throughout the semester, especially since it's a smaller class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if you are interesting in learning strategies to read, write and present scientific information and more about the inner workings of scientific research at Yale. If you are not planning to do research or study a STEM field, do NOT take this course. That being said, this course really isn't that much work and it is very helpful if you are a STEM student! It made me rethink my life choices every single week. Plus, Head Charles is wonderful.
For sure if they wanted to pursue research in STEM. A very helpful course.
100%. Professor Bailyn is such a kind heart, and the skills learned are those that every scientist or mathematician should learn.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in potentially doing scientific research. This course has helped me build the foundations required to conduct research at the undergraduate level, teaching me how to read and understand research papers effectively, write with concision, and communicate results effectively.
Yes, certainly
Yes. I deeply enjoyed this course and felt that I learned a lot. This course will help me in the future.
Yes, great way to destress by talking about interesting topics.
Yes, for anyone looking into research in general or research at Yale, this is a great course.

Absolutely! Bailyn is a great professor and he has really thought about how to make this a good class for non-science majors, and it shows! This class is not a gut, but it's not very difficult either. As someone who kinda dreaded having to take science credits when I have so many humanities classes that I would rather spend my time and money on, Professor Bailyn made the distributional requirement worth my time. Very appreciated
